elements.title: Financial Trust Signal Typography Hierarchy
elements.problem: When hosts evaluate a guest proposal, the most critical data -- combined income, individual income, employment and credit verification -- must register instantly as authoritative and verifiable. Jason's first evaluation question was about income (06:14), and the answer was imprecise ('over 80,000'). On-screen, financial trust signals risk blending into the general visual field if they use the same typographic treatment as secondary information. The host's eye needs to separate 'hard financial data I can evaluate' from 'soft descriptive information I can read later.' Without a distinct typographic register for financial data, the host must cognitively sort information that should be visually pre-sorted.
elements.solution: Use IBM Plex Mono at a prominent weight and size for all hard financial data on evaluation and proposal screens -- combined income, individual income, rent amount, deposit figures, and guarantee amounts. Mono typography signals precision, verifiability, and data-backed claims. Surround financial figures with generous spacing to isolate them from adjacent content. Use Outfit (sans) at medium weight for verification status labels ('Employment Verified', 'Credit Checked') positioned directly adjacent to the mono figures. Reserve Instrument Serif for the section heading ('Financial Summary') to provide warmth and brand continuity. This three-register typographic system (mono for numbers, sans for labels, serif for headings) creates an instant visual grammar: mono means 'this is a fact you can evaluate,' sans means 'this is a status you can trust,' serif means 'this is a section you are entering.'

evidence.quote: What's a total income between both of them? ... I'd have to look that up. I don't have it handy with me right now.
evidence.insight: Jason's first and most urgent evaluation question is about income -- a hard number. The visual treatment of this number on-screen must match the urgency with which the host seeks it: prominent, precise, instantly scannable.

evidence.quote: They've both been vetted. We verified employment credit and previous landlord references as well. And also we guarantee the rent payment to you as the landlord.
evidence.insight: Bryant front-loads trust signals verbally. The visual hierarchy must replicate this verbal pattern: financial verification first, guarantee second, logistics third. Mono type for the financials makes them pop against sans type for everything else.

evidence.quote: It comes down to knowing two things about each idea: (1) How much money or value will this generate? and (2) How much money or time will this cost?
evidence.insight: Cagan's business case framework maps to the host's evaluation: value (income, guarantee) vs. cost (process friction). The typographic hierarchy must make the value side (financial data) visually dominant so the host's internal business case calculation can begin immediately.

evidence.quote: Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono -- signals precision and reliability.
evidence.insight: The taste model explicitly designates mono for trust-bearing data. Financial trust signals on the proposal screen are the highest-stakes application of this principle.

typography: IBM Plex Mono, 600 weight, 24-28px for primary income figures
IBM Plex Mono, 400 weight, 16-18px for secondary financial data (deposit, rent)
Outfit, 500 weight, 14px for verification labels
Instrument Serif, 400 weight, 20-22px for section headings
spacing: xl (40px) above and below the financial summary block
lg (24px) between individual income lines
md (16px) between a financial figure and its verification label
sm (8px) between icon and label in verification badges
new_tokens_needed: typography-scale-financial: a defined type scale specifically for financial data display (24/18/14 hierarchy)
spacing-data-isolation: minimum whitespace around data-critical elements to prevent visual contamination from adjacent content

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Primary income figures (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff) achieve 16.8:1 ratio, far exceeding AA. Verification badges (accent #2d5a3d on accent-light #e8f0eb) achieve approximately 5.2:1, meeting AA for normal text. All financial data must maintain at least 7:1 contrast ratio against its background to meet AAA for this critical information.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Financial figures are the first thing the eye encounters on any evaluation or proposal screen. They sit at the top of the content area, in the largest mono type on the page. No other element on the screen should use a larger font size or bolder weight than the combined income figure. Verification badges sit directly below financial figures, creating a vertical trust stack: number, then proof, then action.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm and trustworthy per taste model. Mono type for financial data signals 'we are precise about the numbers that matter to you' without feeling cold or corporate. The forest green accent on verification badges reinforces trust and stability. The warm surface background (#ffffff over #f6f4f0 page) prevents the data-heavy section from feeling clinical. Serif section headings add the human warmth that balances the precision of mono figures.

elements.title: Mental Model Bridge Visual Callout Pattern
elements.problem: When the platform's process diverges from traditional landlord expectations -- no in-person showings, platform-mediated vetting instead of direct income verification, digital-first lease process -- the host needs an immediate visual signal that this divergence has been anticipated and addressed. Jason repeated his showing concern twice (10:50 and 12:35), escalating from 'a bit odd' to 'this just sounds weird.' On-screen, if the platform simply omits a 'Schedule Showing' button without explanation, the absence creates a trust gap. The visual pattern for divergence explanation must be distinct enough to be noticed during a scan but not alarming enough to read as a warning or error. It must feel like helpful context, not defensive justification.
elements.solution: Create a distinctive inline callout pattern for mental model bridges. Use a surface-warm background (#fdfcfa) with a left border in accent color (#2d5a3d, 3px) to distinguish it from content cards, warning banners, and error states. The callout uses Outfit at regular weight for the body and a slightly bolder weight for the acknowledgment line. Structure: first line acknowledges the expectation in bold ('Most landlords schedule in-person showings'), body explains the platform approach in regular weight, and a final line offers the accommodation or protection as an accent-colored text link. The callout sits inline within the page flow at the exact point where the divergence becomes visible -- next to a proposal with no showing option, next to a vetting section that uses platform format instead of traditional application. Maximum 40 words. No icons that suggest warning or error.

evidence.quote: I've been doing showings. It sounds a bit odd that they don't want to see the place before they move in.
evidence.insight: Jason's first mention of the divergence uses mild language, signaling surprise not rejection. The visual callout should deploy at this moment of mild surprise, before the concern hardens into objection. The callout's visual tone must match this mild-surprise register: informative, not urgent.

evidence.quote: A lot of people are like, this just sounds weird to me that they want to sign a lease without seeing it.
evidence.insight: By the second mention, the concern has escalated and generalized. The visual callout must prevent this escalation by providing the bridge at first encounter, not after repeated friction.

evidence.quote: Technology-powered products do not need to be purely digital. Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences.
evidence.insight: Cagan's principle that the best products blend online and offline validates accommodating the traditional expectation rather than dismissing it. The callout's visual design should feel like a bridge (warm, connecting) not a wall (cold, correcting).

evidence.quote: Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data.
evidence.insight: The callout must feel trustworthy and human, not like a corporate FAQ or legal disclaimer. Rounded corners on the callout card, human language ('Most landlords do this...'), and no corporate tone markers.

typography: Outfit, 600 weight, 14px for the acknowledgment line (first sentence)
Outfit, 400 weight, 14px for the explanation body
Outfit, 500 weight, 14px for the accommodation link in accent color
spacing: md (16px) padding inside the callout
lg (24px) margin above and below the callout to separate it from surrounding content
sm (8px) between the acknowledgment line, body, and accommodation link
new_tokens_needed: border-accent-left: a 3px left-border treatment in accent color for inline contextual callouts, distinct from warning (signal-warn) and error (signal-danger) border treatments
surface-bridge: a dedicated background tone for mental model bridge callouts if surface-warm is used elsewhere and the distinction is needed

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Body text (ink-soft #4a4640 on surface-warm #fdfcfa) achieves approximately 9.5:1, exceeding AA. Acknowledgment line (ink #1a1714 on surface-warm #fdfcfa) achieves approximately 16:1. Accent-colored link text (#2d5a3d on surface-warm #fdfcfa) achieves approximately 6.4:1, meeting AA for normal text. The 3px left border (#2d5a3d) provides sufficient visual distinction without relying solely on color.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The callout is visually subordinate to the primary content (financial data, proposal details) but visually distinct from it. It should be noticed during a scan but not demand first attention. The left accent border serves as a visual flag that says 'contextual note' without competing with the primary hierarchy. The callout never appears at the top of a screen -- it appears inline at the point of divergence, so the host encounters the content first and the bridge explanation second.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm and confident per taste model. The surface-warm background and forest green accent border feel like a gentle aside from a trusted guide, not a system notification. The human language requirement ('Most landlords do this...') aligns with the taste model's emphasis on human language over corporate jargon. Rounded corners (radius-md, 10px) on the callout match the taste model's 'rounded corners' preference and prevent the callout from feeling like a rigid disclaimer box.

elements.title: Progressive Proposal Section Gating with Visual Weight Cascade
elements.problem: Jason's call reveals a strict cognitive decision sequence: money first (06:14), then term (06:43), then furnishing (07:55), then showings (10:18). If the proposal screen presents all information at equal visual weight, the host must cognitively triage to find their starting point. The host's eye needs visual weight to decrease from the financial section (the decision gate) through the term section (secondary evaluation) to the operational section (conditional details). Without a visual weight cascade, the proposal becomes a flat wall of information where everything competes for attention and nothing guides the decision sequence.
elements.solution: Structure the proposal as three visually distinct sections with decreasing typographic weight, background contrast, and spacing density. Section 1 (Financial): surface (#ffffff) card with shadow-md, using the mono type hierarchy from looks-001, with xl (40px) padding. This section sits at the top and has the highest visual mass on the page. Section 2 (Terms): surface-warm (#fdfcfa) card with shadow-sm, using Outfit at medium weights, with lg (24px) padding. Visually lighter than Section 1 but still clearly a distinct block. Section 3 (Operational): bg (#f6f4f0) region with no card elevation, using Outfit at regular weight, with md (16px) padding. The lightest visual treatment, signaling 'conditional details you review after the financials and terms are satisfactory.' Each section is separated by xl (40px) vertical space. The decreasing surface brightness (white to warm to warm-gray) creates a natural visual gravity that pulls the eye from top to bottom in the correct decision sequence.

evidence.quote: What's a total income between both of them? [06:14] ... you were saying something about the term [06:43] ... they're looking for a furnished place [07:55] ... do people want to see the place? [10:18]
evidence.insight: Jason's question sequence is a direct map of his visual priority: financials command the most attention, terms are secondary, operational details are conditional. The visual weight must mirror this sequence.

evidence.quote: They're considering other places as well, right? Yes.
evidence.insight: Both sides have alternatives, creating time pressure. A well-structured visual cascade accelerates the host's decision by pre-sorting information into their natural evaluation order, reducing scan time and enabling faster commitment.

evidence.quote: There is always a ton of things from different parts of the business that need to be done. Companies want to prioritize these ideas into a roadmap.
evidence.insight: Just as product roadmaps must prioritize by impact, proposal screens must prioritize by decision sequence. The visual weight cascade is the screen's roadmap -- it tells the eye where to start and how to progress.

evidence.quote: Warm neutrals as base (not gray, not white -- warm off-whites and tans).
evidence.insight: The three-level surface cascade (white to warm to tan) uses the taste model's warm neutral palette to create hierarchy without introducing cold grays or stark contrasts that would feel corporate.

typography: IBM Plex Mono, 600 weight, 24-28px for primary financial figures (Section 1)
Outfit, 600 weight, 18px for Section 1 heading
Outfit, 500 weight, 16px for Section 2 content
Outfit, 400 weight, 14px for Section 3 content
Instrument Serif, 400 weight, 20px for section headings across all three sections
spacing: xl (40px) vertical gap between sections
xl (40px) padding inside Section 1 card
lg (24px) padding inside Section 2 card
md (16px) padding inside Section 3 region
xxl (60px) top margin above Section 1 to separate from page header
new_tokens_needed: shadow-section-primary: a slightly more prominent shadow than shadow-md for the top-priority proposal section, to ensure the financial card visually lifts above the page
bg-cascade: a named three-step surface cascade (surface > surface-warm > bg) for progressive disclosure layouts

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum across all three sections. Section 1: ink (#1a1714) on surface (#ffffff) achieves 16.8:1. Section 2: ink-soft (#4a4640) on surface-warm (#fdfcfa) achieves approximately 9.5:1. Section 3: ink-soft (#4a4640) on bg (#f6f4f0) achieves approximately 8.2:1. All meet AA and AAA requirements. The visual hierarchy relies on typographic weight and surface tone, not on color coding that would exclude colorblind users.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The host's eye enters at the top-left of Section 1 (the highest-contrast, highest-elevation card) and cascades downward through decreasing visual mass. Section 1 occupies the prime viewport position and uses the heaviest typographic weight. Section 2 is visible below Section 1 without scrolling on desktop (above the fold) but with lighter visual treatment. Section 3 requires a slight scroll or is partially visible, signaling 'review this after the above.' No element in Section 2 or 3 should have equal or greater visual weight than any element in Section 1.
elements.brand_alignment: Premium-accessible per taste model. The three-level surface cascade (white card, warm card, warm background) creates a sophisticated depth hierarchy using the warm neutral palette. The shadow treatments add dimension without feeling heavy. The overall effect is a proposal that feels curated and intentional -- a 'considered presentation' rather than a data dump. This aligns with the taste model's 'confident, not flashy' principle: the hierarchy speaks through structure, not decoration.

elements.title: Synchronous Activation First-Touch Mobile Screen Pattern
elements.problem: The post-call engagement gap is the highest-risk moment in the host journey. Jason ended a 14-minute call with no digital touchpoint -- just a promise of 'an email shortly.' The first-touch screen, sent via text link during or immediately after the call, must be scannable in under 10 seconds on a mobile phone while the host is potentially still on the call. This screen competes with the host's divided attention, their existing Craigslist workflow, and their 6 active showings. If it looks like a marketing landing page, a registration form, or a generic homepage, the host's System 1 assessment rejects it before the content is evaluated. It must look like exactly what the host expects: a summary of the conversation they just had, presented in a way that feels like a natural continuation of the call, not a new product experience.
elements.solution: Design the first-touch mobile screen as a single-viewport, zero-scroll information card. White surface (#ffffff) background with no header navigation, no branding bar, no marketing copy. The screen contains exactly five elements in a vertical stack: (1) Property address in Instrument Serif at 18-20px, which the host recognizes as 'my place.' (2) Guest names in Outfit at 16px bold, connecting to the call. (3) A single-line financial summary in IBM Plex Mono at 16px: income, rent, and guarantee in one scannable row. (4) A single full-width CTA button in accent (#2d5a3d) with white text, radius-md (10px), saying 'Interested -- Tell Me More' or 'Request a Showing.' (5) A subtle footer line in ink-muted (#8a857e) at 12px: 'Sent by [Agent Name] via Split Lease.' Nothing else. No images, no logos above the fold, no explanatory paragraphs, no form fields. The screen is recognizable as 'the thing Bryant just told me about' within 3 seconds.

evidence.quote: Could I get your email, send over some information to you after this call? ... I'll follow up with an email shortly.
evidence.insight: The entire onboarding currently hinges on a future email. The first-touch screen replaces this asynchronous gap with an immediate, scannable summary. Its visual simplicity must match the conversational simplicity of the call -- five facts, one action.

evidence.quote: I had done six total showings, but four of them were like a month ago... recently I only did about two showings.
evidence.insight: Jason has active alternatives. The first-touch screen must capture his attention faster than the mental pull of his existing showing pipeline. Visual simplicity and instant recognition are the mechanisms -- the screen must be comprehensible in a glance.

evidence.quote: Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
evidence.insight: Cagan's principle of blending online and offline is the design brief for this screen: the call (offline) seamlessly transitions to the screen (online) during the same interaction. The visual design must feel like a continuation, not a new beginning.

evidence.quote: Good startups are optimized for learning and moving quickly and normally have very little bureaucracy to slow them down.
evidence.insight: Speed optimization demands visual minimalism. Every element on the first-touch screen must earn its viewport space. If it does not serve recognition or action, it is visual bureaucracy.

typography: Instrument Serif, 400 weight, 18-20px for property address (recognition anchor)
Outfit, 600 weight, 16px for guest names
IBM Plex Mono, 500 weight, 16px for financial summary line
Outfit, 600 weight, 16px for CTA button text (white on accent)
Outfit, 400 weight, 12px for footer attribution
spacing: lg (24px) top padding to separate content from status bar
lg (24px) between each of the five elements
xl (40px) above the CTA button to create visual separation from informational content
md (16px) horizontal padding (mobile edge margins)
sm (8px) padding inside the CTA button beyond text height
new_tokens_needed: layout-first-touch: a defined single-viewport layout constraint (max 5 elements, zero scroll, no navigation chrome) for time-critical first-impression screens
cta-primary-height: minimum touch target height for primary CTA buttons on mobile (48px per WCAG 2.5.5)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum, targeting AAA where possible due to the divided-attention context. Property address (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff): 16.8:1 (AAA). Financial summary (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff): 16.8:1 (AAA). CTA button (white #ffffff on accent #2d5a3d): approximately 5.9:1 (AA for large text; at 16px bold, this meets AA). Footer text (ink-muted #8a857e on surface #ffffff): approximately 3.7:1 -- this is intentionally below AA for body text because the footer is supplementary, but should be tested and potentially darkened to ink-ghost or ink-soft if accessibility audits require it.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The host's eye path moves in a straight vertical line: address (recognition), names (connection), money (evaluation), button (action), attribution (context). No horizontal scanning required. No competing elements in the peripheral field. The CTA button is the only colored element on the screen (accent green on white), making it the natural terminus of the eye path. The property address at the top serves as the 'recognition anchor' -- if the host sees their address, they keep scanning; if not, something went wrong.
elements.brand_alignment: Confident, not flashy per taste model. The first-touch screen achieves premium feel through radical simplicity -- five elements, generous spacing, zero decoration. This is the taste model's 'the product speaks through clarity, not decoration' principle at its most extreme. The absence of branding, logos, and marketing copy is itself a brand statement: 'we respect your time and attention enough to show you only what matters right now.' The warm serif for the address and the precise mono for the finances create the characteristic SplitLease typographic personality in minimal space.

elements.title: Configurable Furniture Inventory Visual Grid
elements.problem: Jason's apartment has negotiable furniture: a bed (good), a futon ('not the highest quality'), 4 tables/desks (too many, willing to remove some), and cleaning plans that depend on the tenant. A binary 'furnished: yes/no' checkbox cannot express this reality. The visual treatment of configurable property attributes must communicate three distinct states (Included, Available, Removable) at a glance while also supporting inline condition notes for items with caveats. If the visual treatment is too complex, hosts will skip it; if too simple, it loses the nuance that prevents post-match disputes. The grid must feel like a natural, lightweight part of the listing flow, not a separate inventory management tool.
elements.solution: Present furniture items as a compact visual grid where each item occupies a single horizontal row with three visual zones: (1) Item name and state indicator on the left, using a small colored dot or pill badge to show state -- accent (#2d5a3d) for Included, signal-info (#2d5a8a) for Available, ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) for Removable. (2) An optional condition note in the center, in ink-muted at small type (13px), visible only for 'Available' items. (3) A subtle toggle or state selector on the right. Use a light horizontal divider (border #e2dfd9) between rows. The grid sits on a surface-warm (#fdfcfa) background to visually group it as a cohesive section. During proposal negotiation, items with guest change requests gain a left border in signal-info (#2d5a8a) and a subtle info-bg background to highlight what needs the host's attention. Items with no changes remain visually quiet.

evidence.quote: There's actually too many tables. So I can just move out a couple of the tables. There's four tables and desks. Really need all of that.
evidence.insight: Jason's willingness to remove items means the visual system must show 'this item can go' as clearly as 'this item stays.' The three-state model (Included/Available/Removable) with color-coded indicators prevents the ambiguity that leads to post-match disputes.

evidence.quote: It can be flipped on, but it's not the highest quality. I can let them know.
evidence.insight: Jason is transparent about the futon's condition. The condition note field in the 'Available' state lets hosts add honest caveats inline, visible to guests during proposal review. The muted typography signals 'honest note' not 'warning label.'

evidence.quote: Behind every great product is someone who led the team to combine technology and design to solve real customer problems.
evidence.insight: The real problem is that hosts have nuanced, negotiable property configurations that binary forms cannot capture. The visual grid solves this by making complexity scannable without making it overwhelming.

evidence.quote: Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.
evidence.insight: The furniture grid must feel lightweight and intuitive -- not like enterprise inventory management software. Small colored dots, clean rows, and minimal chrome achieve the premium-accessible balance.

typography: Outfit, 500 weight, 15px for item names
Outfit, 400 weight, 13px for condition notes in ink-muted
Outfit, 500 weight, 12px for state pill badges (uppercase tracking)
spacing: md (16px) vertical padding per row
md (16px) horizontal padding inside the grid container
sm (8px) between the state dot/pill and the item name
xs (4px) between the item name and the condition note
lg (24px) margin above and below the entire grid section
new_tokens_needed: state-dot-included: a small (8px) circle in accent color for 'Included' state indicator
state-dot-available: same in signal-info for 'Available' state
state-dot-removable: same in ink-ghost for 'Removable' state
row-highlight-request: a subtle left-border + background treatment for grid rows with pending guest change requests

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Item names (ink #1a1714 on surface-warm #fdfcfa): approximately 16:1 (AAA). Condition notes (ink-muted #8a857e on surface-warm #fdfcfa): approximately 3.5:1 -- this falls below AA for normal text at 13px. Recommendation: use ink-soft (#4a4640) instead for condition notes, which achieves approximately 9.5:1 while still appearing visually subordinate. State pill badges must meet AA against their own background color. The colored state dots are supplemented by text labels ('Included', 'Available', 'Removable') to ensure colorblind accessibility.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The grid is visually subordinate to the financial and term sections of a proposal (it lives in the operational details zone per looks-003). Within the grid, included items have the strongest visual presence (accent-colored indicator), available items have medium presence (info-colored indicator with condition note), and removable items have the lightest presence (ghost-colored indicator). During proposal negotiation, items with change requests elevate above the default hierarchy through the info-bg highlight, drawing the host's attention to what needs action.
elements.brand_alignment: Trustworthy, not corporate per taste model. The grid uses color sparingly -- small dots and pills, not filled backgrounds -- keeping the overall feel lightweight and human. The condition notes in muted type feel like honest asides, not formal disclosures. The rounded corners on pill badges (radius-full, 9999px) and the warm surface background maintain the brand's approachable aesthetic. The three-state model itself embodies the taste model's emphasis on 'real data' -- it shows the actual, negotiable state of the property rather than a sanitized binary.

elements.title: Competitive Context Timeline Badge
elements.problem: Both sides of Jason's match have active alternatives. Jason asks 'they're considering other places as well, right?' (13:20), and the guests are 'taking a look at a couple other places' (13:26). The host needs factual competitive context to calibrate decision timing, but this context must not feel like pressure marketing (countdown timers, red urgency banners) or social proof manipulation ('12 other hosts responded faster'). The visual challenge is to present time-sensitive information in a way that feels neutral and informative -- like checking a train departure board -- rather than alarming or manipulative. The wrong visual treatment turns helpful context into hostile pressure.
elements.solution: Display competitive context as a subtle, neutral-toned badge or status line positioned below the proposal's primary content and above the CTA action zone. Use a single line of text in Outfit at regular weight, 13-14px, in ink-muted (#8a857e) color: 'Ariel and Amber plan to decide by [date]' or 'Proposal sent [X] days ago.' No icons, no colored backgrounds, no progress bars. The badge sits on the page background (bg #f6f4f0), not on a card surface, so it reads as ambient context rather than highlighted content. If the proposal has been open for more than 48 hours without action, the text color shifts from ink-muted to ink-soft (#4a4640) -- a subtle darkening that increases visibility without introducing urgency colors. Never use signal-warn or signal-danger colors for competitive context. The timeline date uses mono type (IBM Plex Mono, 13px) to signal factual precision.

evidence.quote: They're considering other places as well, right? Yes. Yep. They're taking a look at a couple other places.
evidence.insight: Jason proactively asks about competitive context. He wants this information. The visual treatment should deliver it as neutrally as he received it in conversation -- a factual statement, not a pressure tactic.

evidence.quote: I'll follow up with an email shortly. And like I said, if you have questions for me, text email either way, anytime works.
evidence.insight: The call ends with zero timeline visibility. 'Shortly' and 'anytime' create open-ended ambiguity. The timeline badge replaces this ambiguity with specific, visible dates that help the host plan their decision without feeling rushed.

evidence.quote: The reality of life in the startup is that you are in a race to achieve product/market fit before you run out of money.
evidence.insight: Cagan's funding-runway metaphor translates to each host interaction having a conversion runway. Making this runway visible -- through a date, not a countdown -- aligns the host's actions with the platform's conversion needs without manipulation.

evidence.quote: Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.
evidence.insight: The timeline badge embodies confident restraint. It provides clarity (a specific date) without flashiness (no countdown timers, no red text, no animated urgency indicators). The subtlety of the treatment is itself a trust signal.

typography: Outfit, 400 weight, 13-14px for the context line
IBM Plex Mono, 400 weight, 13px for dates and day-counts within the context line
spacing: lg (24px) above the timeline badge to separate from proposal content
md (16px) below the timeline badge before the CTA zone
xs (4px) padding above and below the text line if a subtle divider is used above
new_tokens_needed: ink-muted-to-soft-transition: a defined color transition from ink-muted to ink-soft that triggers after 48 hours of proposal inactivity, implemented as a class toggle rather than an animation
timeline-mono-inline: a convention for embedding mono-typed date fragments within sans-typed context lines

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA consideration. Default state: ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg (#f6f4f0) achieves approximately 2.9:1 -- this is intentionally below AA body text threshold because the timeline is supplementary ambient information. The subtle treatment is a design choice to prevent urgency perception. However, for accessibility compliance, the 48-hour escalation to ink-soft (#4a4640 on #f6f4f0, approximately 6.9:1) brings the text to AA compliance. If accessibility audits require the default state to also meet AA, use ink-soft as the default and ink (#1a1714) as the escalation.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The timeline badge is the lowest-priority visual element on the proposal screen. It sits below all proposal content and above the action zone, functioning as ambient context the host notices peripherally during the decision process. It never competes with financial data, term details, or the CTA button. The mono-typed date within the context line provides a subtle visual anchor that draws the eye to the most actionable piece of information (the date) without elevating the entire badge.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm and trustworthy per taste model. The timeline badge treats the host as an intelligent adult who can process factual information and make their own timing decisions. No manipulation, no urgency theater. The muted color and small type signal 'we are giving you useful context' not 'we are pressuring you to act.' This aligns with the taste model's 'trustworthy, not corporate' principle -- corporate products use countdown timers; trustworthy products share dates.

elements.title: Operational Knowledge House Manual Card System
elements.problem: Jason spent nearly a quarter of his call on parking logistics (03:15-05:14) and additional time on furniture conditions (08:19-09:27) and building rules. This operational knowledge is critical to guest satisfaction but has no visual home in a standard listing. When this knowledge is captured, it needs a visual treatment that feels like helpful, host-authored content -- not like a disclaimer, not like a formal amenity list, and not like a legal document. The visual pattern must work both during listing creation (where the host authors the content) and during the active lease (where guests read it). It must feel personal and authentic -- these are the host's own words about their own property.
elements.solution: Present operational knowledge as a system of compact cards, each representing one knowledge category: Parking, Building Access, Furniture and Amenities, Neighborhood, and Building Rules. Each card has a simple icon or emoji at top-left, a category title in Outfit bold at 15px, and 1-3 sentences of host-authored content in Outfit regular at 14px. Cards use surface (#ffffff) background with radius-md (10px) and shadow-sm, arranged in a responsive grid (2 columns on desktop, single column on mobile). During listing creation, empty cards appear with a dotted border (border #e2dfd9, dashed) and a conversational prompt: 'What should guests know about parking near your place?' The prompt uses ink-muted color to feel like a gentle invitation, not a required field. Completed cards replace the dotted border with a solid subtle border and show the host's content. A small completion indicator at the section level ('3 of 5 tips added') in accent color provides gentle motivation without pressure.

evidence.quote: Parking battery park city, the parking is quite tough because it's the business district... street cleaning once a week... sometimes it'll take an hour if it's maybe Saturday night.
evidence.insight: Jason's parking knowledge is detailed, time-sensitive, and would take guests days to learn independently. The card format captures this knowledge in a scannable, categorized format that guests can reference before and during their stay.

evidence.quote: People come in and they're like, oh, there's like a dirt stain... but they could also get another bed or another type of thing to put on top of it.
evidence.insight: Jason anticipates guest reactions and offers solutions proactively. The card format lets him share these preemptive notes in a format that feels helpful rather than defensive -- 'here is what you should know' not 'here is our disclaimer.'

evidence.quote: Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
evidence.insight: The house manual cards are the visual bridge between the host's offline expertise and the guest's online preparation. They make the offline experience accessible before the guest arrives.

evidence.quote: The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey. Generic states are a failure.
evidence.insight: The house manual cards are inherently personalized -- they contain the specific host's words about their specific property. Empty prompt states during listing creation and completed states during guest viewing reflect the taste model's anti-generic principle.

typography: Outfit, 600 weight, 15px for card category titles
Outfit, 400 weight, 14px for host-authored content
Outfit, 400 weight, 14px in ink-muted for empty-state prompts
Outfit, 500 weight, 13px in accent for completion indicator
spacing: md (16px) padding inside each card
md (16px) gap between cards in the grid
lg (24px) above and below the card section
sm (8px) between the category icon and the title
sm (8px) between the title and the content body
new_tokens_needed: border-dashed-prompt: a dashed border treatment (1px dashed border-color) for empty-state cards with conversational prompts, visually distinct from solid content borders and error borders
icon-category-operational: a small icon set (5 icons for parking, access, furniture, neighborhood, rules) at 20px, in ink-soft color, for house manual card headers

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Card titles (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff): 16.8:1 (AAA). Host content (ink-soft #4a4640 on surface #ffffff): 10.4:1 (AAA). Empty-state prompts (ink-muted #8a857e on surface #ffffff): approximately 4.0:1 -- marginally meets AA for 14px text (AA requires 4.5:1 for normal text). Recommendation: use a slightly darker prompt color or increase to 15px to ensure compliance. Completion indicator (accent #2d5a3d on bg #f6f4f0): approximately 5.5:1, meeting AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The house manual cards are visually subordinate to property photos, pricing, and availability information on the listing. They occupy a 'Prepare for Your Stay' section that the guest reaches after evaluating the primary listing content. Within the card system, the category title is the scan target (bold, 15px), allowing guests to find the relevant card (e.g., 'Parking') without reading all content. During listing creation, empty-state cards are visually lighter than completed cards (dashed border vs. solid border, muted prompt vs. ink content), naturally drawing the host's eye to what remains to be filled.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm and human per taste model. The cards feel like notes from a thoughtful host, not like a hotel welcome packet. The conversational prompts ('What should guests know about...') use human language per the taste model. Rounded corners (radius-md), light shadows (shadow-sm), and warm surface tones maintain the brand's approachable aesthetic. The completion indicator in accent green provides gentle encouragement without gamification or pressure, aligning with the trustworthy personality.
